SKILL_NAME: Identify the writing performance task of a fifth-grade argumentative writing prompt
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Identify fifth-grade argumentative writing prompt
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS:
This synthesizes writing skills (and author's craft analysis skills) into one.

Some examples of what is identified or critiqued:
* the question that needs answering
* the topic to be explained
* position to take
* write to a specific purpose
* take a specific tone or have a specific effect on the reader

For Freckle, these skills come at the beginning and end of a multi-grade writing unit. In second grade, the focus is on the very first aspect of that--identifying the goal of the writing. In fifth grade, the focus tends to be on critiquing how well it was accomplished.
DEV_NOTE: Delivery 12 Release - skills beyond LPs

SKILL_CREATION_RATIONALE: These skills operate at the sentence level and focus on the mechanics of figurative language interpretation rather than extended text analysis. Students demonstrate understanding of the comparative relationships within individual figurative expressions, making these skills foundational building blocks that can be applied across any text type encountered in fifth-grade reading.
DEV_NOTE: Delivery 12 Release - skills beyond LPs

SKILL_NAME: Identify the performance task of a second-grade informative writing prompt
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Identify informative writing performance task
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS:
This synthesizes writing skills (and author's craft analysis skills) into one. The "task" is essentially the goal of the writing assignment or prompt.

Some examples of what is identified or critiqued:
* the question that needs answering
* the topic to be explained
* position to take
* write to a specific purpose
* take a specific tone or have a specific effect on the reader

For Freckle, these skills come at the beginning and end of a multi-grade writing unit. In second grade, the focus is on the very first aspect of that--identifying the goal of the writing.
DEV_NOTE: Delivery 12 Release - skills beyond LPs

Definition: This skill is an extension beyond the introduction of a narrator and involves consistently maintaining a specific viewpoint throughout the narrative. It includes the narrator's perspective, voice, and how they convey the story.
Focus: The emphasis is on the consistency and depth of the narrative viewpoint, ensuring that the reader can clearly understand and follow the narrator's perspective.

SKILL_NAME: Establish and maintain a consistent narrative perspective in eighth-grade narrative writing
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Establish consistent narrative perspective in eighth-grade narrative writing
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS:
Definition: This skill is an extension beyond the introduction of a narrator and involves consistently maintaining a specific viewpoint throughout the narrative. It includes the narrator's perspective, voice, and how they convey the story.
Focus: The emphasis is on the consistency and depth of the narrative viewpoint, ensuring that the reader can clearly understand and follow the narrator's perspective.

This is a prereq of new skill Purp05USP5 as well as existing USP skills: Purp04Info3 and Purp04Lit2. Feat02USP2 is a prerequisite of this one. The following RSL skills may also be prerequisites:
Identify and describe the function of nouns in a sentence; Identify and describe the function of verbs in a sentence.

SKILL_NAME: Identify word origins (e.g., Latin, Greek) using dictionaries to build awareness of how to apply word morphology when encoding words
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Identify word origins when encoding
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS: Essentially a "spelling bee" skill. For example, knowing whether a word is Greek or Latin in origin helps you know how to pluralize it. Meaning is very secondary to this skill. Related skills: Spell03USP6 Spell grade-appropriate words using knowledge of prefixes (e.g., reread, misunderstand, undone) Spell03USP7 Spell grade-appropriate words using knowledge of suffixes and how base words can change (e.g., taking, hurries, running) However these do not go far enough to connect the spellings to word origins.
SKILL_CREATION_RATIONALE: Not covered in USP. Existing spelling skills involve morphology but not an understanding of word origins or using dictionaries

SKILL_NAME: Solve a mathematical or real-world problem by plotting and using polygons on a coordinate plane
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Solve a mathematical or real-world problem by plotting and using polygons on a coordinate plane
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS:
Students will be able to solve a real-world or mathematical problem by plotting and using polygons on a coordinate plane. Problem types include finding the perimeter or area of a polygon. Polygons must be rectangles, squares, triangles, or composed of these shapes. When finding the perimeter, the joining points should have the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate. When finding the area, polygons can be deconstructed into the shapes it is composed of (if necessary). Problems can include students plotting the polygon first or giving students an already graphed polygon.

For example, graph the points (6,4), (6,1), (9,1), (9,4) and find the area and perimeter.
DEV_NOTE: Delivery 12 Release - skills beyond LPs

PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS:
Students will be able to describe a data set using measures of center and variability (spread). Students will be able to describe displays based on measures of center (mean and median) and measures of variability (interquartile range and mean absolute deviation) as well as describe any overall patterns or striking deviations from the overall pattern with reference to the context in which the data is gathered.

Examples: describing distributions, calculating means of center and variability, calculate mean absolute deviation, identify outliers and explain effects

SKILL_NAME: Use relative frequencies in a two-way table to describe a possible association between two variables
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Describe possible association between variables
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS: Students will understand that a pattern of association can be seen in bivariate categorical data by displaying frequencies and relative frequencies in a two-way table. Relative frequencies can reveal whether there is a possible association between two variables. If the relative frequencies of each category are about the same, there is little or no association between the categories; however, if they differ, there is some evidence of an association between the categories. For example, suppose there is a large difference in the number of middle school students who prefer horses and the number of elementary students who prefer pigs. In that case, there is likely an association between the grade levels and animal choices.

SKILL_NAME: Compare the size of a product to the size of one factor on the basis of the size of the other factor
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Compare the product size to the size of one factor on the basis of the size of the other factor
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS: Given a multiplication expression involving two whole numbers, two fractions, or a whole number and a fraction, students will determine whether the product is greater than, less than, or equal to the other factor without using multiplication. Instead, students must recognize that multiplying any factor by a fraction less than 1 results in a product less than the original factor; multiplying any factor by a fraction greater than 1 results in a product greater than the original fraction; and multiplying any factor by a fraction equivalent to 1 results in a product equal to the original factor. Students can use comparison symbols <, >, or = to complete inequalities (e.g. 2/3 x 1/2 < 2/3).
DEV_NOTE: Delivery 12 Release - skills beyond LPs

SKILL_NAME: Partition 2-dimensional shapes and express the area of each part as a unit fraction
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Partition 2-dimensional shapes and express the area of each part as a unit fraction
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS: Students partition regular polygons (beyond circles and squares) into equal parts and identify each part as a unit fraction of the whole in fraction form. Instruction includes recognizing that when they partition congruent 2D shapes into unit fractions that equal shares do not have to be the same shape. (Example: partitioning a rectangle horizontally versus vertically into fourths is the same even though they look different).

SKILL_NAME: Substitute to determine whether a positive number is a solution to an inequality of the form x>c, x<c, x≤c, or x≥c
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Substitute to determine whether a positive number is a solution to a simple inequality
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS:
Given a positive number, students will be able to substitute the value into an inequality to determine if it is a solution. For this skill, the inequalities should be limited to x > c and x < c using symbols <, >, ≤, ≥. Instruction should include when the variable is on either side of the inequality symbol.

For example, x = 10 is a solution to 10 ≤ x but is not a solution to 10 < x.

SKILL_NAME: Substitute to determine whether a positive number is a solution to a one-step equation
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Substitute to determine whether a positive number is a solution to a one-step equation
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS:
Given a positive number, students will be able to substitute the value into an equation to determine if it is a solution. For this skill, the equations should be limited to one-step (x + p = q or px = q) and values to be substitutes are limited to positive rational numbers. Instruction should begin with substituting positive whole numbers and can extend to fractions and decimals.

For example, is x = 12 a solution to 15 + x = 27? Yes because 15 + (12) = 27
DEV_NOTE: Delivery 12 Release - skills beyond LPs

Instruction includes relating the decomposition of a kilogram to place value and the base ten system. Students should be able to use skip counting to read a spring scale with different intervals.

PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS: Students will be able to identify addition patterns or patterns in the multiplication table. Instruction should include how the table is organized and how to utilize it and then identify arithmetic patterns such as 1. The products in each row and column increase by the same amount (skip counting). 2. Multiples of even numbers (2, 4, 6, and 8) are always even numbers. 3. Multiples of even numbers and odd numbers are always even numbers. 4. Multiples of odd numbers and odd numbers are always odd numbers.

PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS: Students will understand the rules for dividing signed numbers. SKILL_NAME: Identify a common irrational number
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Identify a common irrational number
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS:
Students will be able to identify common irrational numbers. These include, but are not limited to, the square roots of 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, and 10.

For instance, when solving the equation 
x^2 = 8, the solution is the square root of 8. This value is an irrational number and cannot be simplified further, except when expressed as a decimal.

SKILL_NAME: Determine if a function is linear or nonlinear
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Determine if a function is linear or nonlinear
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS:
Students will be able to recognize that the equation y = mx + b defines a linear function that is a straight line and may not go through the origin. Linear functions do not have exponents larger than 1 and must be able to be put in the format y = mx + b.

For example, A = s^2 is not in the form y = mx + b and has an exponent larger than 1, therefore the graph is not linear.

SKILL_NAME: Solve a system of linear equations in two variables by graphing
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Solve a system of linear equations by graphing
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS: Students will be able to solve a system of linear equations by graphing. Instruction should include reviewing how to graph a linear equation and systems that have both equations in slope intercept form, one equation in slope intercept form and one that needs to be rearranged, or both equations needing to be rearranged to graph. Vertical (x = 5) and horizontal (y = 5) equations can be used. For example, graph the system y = 2x +  6 and y = -x + 18. The solution can be seen at (4, 14).

SKILL_NAME: Understand scales and scale drawings
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Understand scales and scale drawings
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS: Students will understand how to identify and calculate scales, scale drawings, and scale copies. For example, if the scale factor is 2, what will happen to the original image?
SKILL_CREATION_RATIONALE: the intent is a low level understanding of scales like identifying the scale or asking students to explain what will happen when given different scales
DEV_NOTE: Delivery 12 Release - skills beyond LPs

SKILL_NAME: Describe the effect of a rotation on a plane figure using coordinates
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Describe the effect of a rotation on a plane figure using coordinates
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS:
Students will be able to describe the effect of a rotation on a plane figure using coordinates. This includes using rotation rules like the following to identify points in the rotated figure. Figures are limited to 90°, 180°, and 270° rotations.

Some simple examples include:
90° counterclockwise or  270° clockwise (around the origin): (x, y) → (-y, x)
90° clockwise or 270° counterclockwise(around the origin): (x, y) → (y, -x)
180° counterclockwise or clockwise (around the origin): (x, y) → (-x, -y)

For example, if a triangle is rotated around the origin 270° counterclockwise, each vertices would use the rule (x, y) → (y, -x) to find the new points.
DEV_NOTE: Delivery 12 Release - skills beyond LPs

SKILL_NAME: Describe the effect of a reflection on a plane figure using coordinates
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Describe the effect of a reflection on a plane figure using coordinates
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS:
Students will be able to describe the effect of a reflection on a plane figure using coordinates. This includes using reflection rules like the following to identify points in the reflected figure. It is recommended that reflections are limited to the axes.
 
reflection over x-axis: (x, y) → (x, -y)
reflection over y-axis: (x, y) → (-x, y)

For example, if a triangle is reflection over the x-axis, all the y-values would change to their opposite.

SKILL_NAME: Recognize when ordered pairs are reflections of each other

SKILL_NAME: Describe the effect of a translation on a plane figure using coordinates
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Describe the effect of a translation on a plane figure using coordinates
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS:
Students will be able to describe the effect of a translation on a plane figure using coordinates. This includes using translation rules like the following to identify points in the translated figure.
 
(x, y) →  (x ± h), (y ± k) where h shows a horizontal shift, and k shows a vertical shift

For example, if a triangle is translated up to three units, each y value for the vertices would increase by 3.
DEV_NOTE: Delivery 12 Release - skills beyond LPs

SKILL_NAME: Add and subtract within 20 using properties of operations
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Add and subtract within 20 using properties of operations
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS: Students should be able to apply properties of operations to add and subtract numbers. This includes using the Commutative Property to recognize that the order of addends does not change the sum. They should also apply the Associative Property, understanding that changing the grouping of addends does not affect the result. Additionally, students should utilize the Distributive Property to break down numbers and simplify calculations.

PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS: Students will use a written algorithm to fluently add and subtract within 1,000,000 given number expressions. Addition and subtraction expressions can include problems that require no grouping, as well as those that do require regrouping, including subtraction across zeroes. For addition problems, the sum should not exceed 1,000,000, while for subtraction problems the minuend should not exceed 1,000,000.

PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS: Students should be able to count to answer “how many?” questions about as many as 20 things arranged in a line, a rectangular array, or a circle, or as many as 10 things in a scattered configuration. When counting scattered images, instruction should begin with counting all the scattered images and then extend to counting only certain scattered things within a mixed image. For example, "count only the blue birds."

SKILL_NAME: Apply properties of operations when multiplying or dividing whole numbers within 100
SKILL_SHORT_NAME: Apply properties of operations when multiplying or dividing whole numbers within 100
PEDAGOGICAL_LIMITS: Students can demonstrate use of the associative, commutative and distributive properties even if they are not using the specific academic vocabulary. Associative property - students demonstrate that changing the grouping of numbers being multiplied doesn't change the result [(2×3)×4 is the same as 2×(3×4)]. Commutative property - changing order of numbers doesn't change the result [2×3 is the same as 3×2]. Distributive property -  multiplication distributes over addition [ 2×(3+4) is the same as (2×3)+(2×4)]
DEV_NOTE: Delivery 12 Release - skills beyond LPs
